nba.parsers.draftkings module¶

class nba.parsers.draftkings.DraftKingsNBAParser¶

Contest entries Draftkings salaries

contest_lineups(contest_id, fh)¶

Takes list of lines from Draft Kings result file, returns entry dictionary

Parameters:lines (param) – full contest entry line
Returns:entries – List of contest entry dictionaries
Return type:list

nba.parsers.fantasylabs module¶

class nba.parsers.fantasylabs.FantasyLabsNBAParser(**kwargs)¶

Bases: object

Usage:

p = FantasyLabsNBAParser() games = p.games(games_json) model = p.model(model_json)

for model_json in models:
p.model(model_json)

TODO: can make FantasyLabsParser base class Most of this code is identical with FantasyLabsNFLParser

games(content, **kwargs)¶

Parses json that is list of games

Usage:
games = p.games(games_json) games = p.games(games_json, omit=[])
model(content, site, gamedate)¶

Parses json associated with model (player stats / projections) The model has 3 dicts for each player: DraftKings, FanDuel, Yahoo SourceIds: 4 is DK, 11 is Yahoo, 3 is FD

Parameters:model_day – list of dict representing player model
Returns:list of parsed models
Return type:players
Usage:
model = p.model(content) model = p.model(content, omit_properties=[]) model = p.model(content, omit_other=[])

nba.parsers.nbacom module¶

class nba.parsers.nbacom.NBAComParser¶

Bases: object

Parses json endpoints of stats.nba.com into lists of dictionaries

Usage:

s = NBAComScraper() jsondoc = s.player_stats() p = NBAComParser() stats = p.player_stats(jsondoc)

content = s.teams() teams = p.teams(content)

boxscore(content, game_date=None)¶

Represents single nba.com boxscore (base)

Parameters:
  • content (dict) – parsed json
  • game_date (str) – string representing date of game for boxscore
Returns:

players – dictionary of stats for each player teams(list): dictionary of stats for each team starter_bench(list): dictionary of stats broken down by starter/bench
Return type:

list
boxscore_advanced(content, game_date=None)¶

Represents single nba.com boxscore (advanced)

Parameters:
  • content (dict) – parsed json
  • game_date (str) – string representing date of game for boxscore
Returns:

players – dictionary of stats for each player teams(list): dictionary of stats for each team starter_bench(list): dictionary of stats broken down by starter/bench
Return type:

list
merge_boxscores(base_boxscore, advanced_boxscore)¶

Base and player advanced boxscores from same game

Parameters:
  • base_boxscore (dict) – base boxscore
  • advanced_boxscore (dict) – advanced boxscore
Returns:

merged(dict) or None

Dictionary about individual player, includes name, id, etc.

playerstats(content, stat_date=None)¶

Document has one line of stats per player

Parameters:
  • content (dict) – parsed json from nba.com
  • stat_date (str) – in YYYY-YY format (2015-16)
Returns:

ps – list of dictionaries, each one is a player’s stats
Return type:

list
scoreboard(content, game_date=None)¶
Parameters:
  • content (str) – json string
  • game_date (str) – date string of the day of scoreboard
Returns:

sb – {‘date’: game_date, ‘game_headers’: game_headers.values(), ‘game_linescores’: game_linescores, ‘standings’: standings}
Return type:

dict
season_gamelogs(content, player_or_team)¶
team_dashboard(content)¶

Dashboard has keys: parameters, overall, location, days_rest, wins_losses The value of each key is a list of dictionaries parameters: 1 item in list overall: 1 item in list location: 2 items - home and away days_rest: multiple items that vary - 0 days, 1 day, 2 days, 3 days, 4 days wins_losses: 2 items - wins and losses

team_opponent_dashboard(content)¶

Returns list of dictionaries, stats of opponents vs. each team

teams(content)¶

Returns list of string - “1610612737”,”ATL” TODO: parse this into dictionaries

teamstats(content, stat_date=None)¶

nba.parsers.nbastuffer module¶

class nba.parsers.nbastuffer.NBAStufferParser(**kwargs)¶

Parses xls file of NBA game info from nbastuffer.com into game dictionaries

Example

p = NBAStufferParser() fn=’stuffer.xlsx’ wb = xlrd.open_workbook(fn) sheet = wb.sheet_by_index(0) if sheet:

games = p.xlsx_game_pairs(sheet, p.xlsx_headers(sheet))
game_pairs(rows, headers)¶

Goes through data rows two at a time (grouped by home/away team in same game) Returns list of (list of 2 dictionaries (home and away info) that represents one game)

headers(row)¶

Takes first row of sheet or csv file and returns lowercase column header with no spaces

xlsx_game_pairs(sheet, headers)¶

Goes through data rows two at a time (grouped by home/away team in same game) Returns list of (list of 2 dictionaries (home and away info) that represents one game)

xlsx_headers(sheet)¶

Takes first row of sheet and returns lowercase column header with no spaces Still need to address issue of starting players, format in spreadsheet is off

nba.parsers.pinnacle module¶

PinnacleNBAParser.py http://xml.pinnaclesports.com/pinnaclefeed.aspx?sporttype=Basketball&sportsubtype=nba

class nba.parsers.pinnacle.PinnacleNBAParser(**kwargs)¶

Bases: object

Takes xml from scraper, returns list of game dictionaries

Usage:

p = PinnacleNBAParser()

with open(‘/home/sansbacon/1.xml’, ‘r’) as infile:

xml = infile.read()

  • OR -

s = PinnacleNBAScraper() xml = s.odds() games = p.odds(xml) p.to_csv(games, date) p.to_tsv(games, date) p.to_fw(games, date)

odds(xml, game_date_cst)¶

Takes xml in, returns sorted and filtered list of game dictionaries: game_date_cst in YYYY-MM-DD format

to_csv(games, datestr)¶

Takes list of game dictionaries, outputs csv

to_fw(games, datestr)¶

Takes list of game dictionaries, outputs fixed-width table

to_tsv(games, datestr)¶

Takes list of game dictionaries, outputs csv

nba.parsers.rotoguru module¶

class nba.parsers.rotoguru.RotoGuruNBAParser¶
Usage:

site = ‘dk’ p = RotoGuruNBAParser()

from RotoGuruNBAScraper import RotoGuruNBAScraper s = RotoGuruNBAScraper() content = s.salaries_day(‘2015-12-09’, ‘dk’) salaries = p.salaries(content, site) players = p.players(content, site)

players(content, site)¶

Returns list of dictionaries with player salary/points information from rotoguru

Parameters:
  • content (str) – HTML string
  • site (str) – name of site (‘dk’, ‘fd’, ‘yh’, etc.)
Returns:

players – list of dictionaries representing player & his salary on a given date on a given site
Return type:

list
Usage:
players = p.players(content, ‘dk’)
salaries(content, site)¶

Returns list of dictionaries with player salary information

Parameters:
  • content (str) – HTML string
  • site (str) – name of site (‘dk’, ‘fd’, ‘yh’, etc.)
Returns:

salaries – list of dictionaries representing player & his salary on a given date on a given site
Return type:

list
Usage:
salaries = p.salaries(content, ‘dk’)
